requiredMaterials.title: Fundamentals of Heat and Mass Transfer

requiredMaterials.options: Looseleaf copy or rent E-book at https://booklist.byu.edu/Home/Mybooklist

courseOverview: Heat transfer is the study of energy transfer due to temperature difference, rates of transfer, and resulting temperature distributions. Course provides advanced undergraduate engineering students with knowledge and understanding of fundamentals of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer modes and relations used to calculate heat transfer rates.

learningOutcomes.description: Model heat transfer processes by identifying relevant heat transfer modes and applying conservation of mass and energy

Describe physical mechanisms of conduction; use Fourier's law to model conduction heat rate; apply conservation principles to develop heat diffusion equation; solve for simplified scenarios using analytical/numerical methods

Describe physical phenomena of convection; use non-dimensional parameters and empirical correlations to predict convective heat transfer coefficients for laminar or turbulent flows; apply Newton's law of cooling

Describe physical mechanisms of radiation; apply relations to model intensity and radiative heat flux; determine radiative properties; apply models for net radiative heat rate and radiative exchange between diffuse, gray surfaces

courseTopics: Heat diffusion equation and boundary conditions
1D steady state conduction and thermal resistance
Radial systems and conduction with thermal energy generation
Transient conduction: lumped capacitance and spatial effects
External flow: flat plates, spheres, cylinders
Internal flow: boundary layers and energy balance
Convection correlations: laminar, turbulent, circular, non-circular
Radiation exchange with diffuse, gray surfaces
Radiation shields and multimode heat transfer
